PaperTitle: Towards Better Detection and Analysis of Massive Spatiotemporal Co-Occurrence Patterns

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Loads heterogeneous urban data from multiple domains, including traffic status, air quality, and weather data into the system.
Outputs: Raw spatiotemporal datasets for indexing and mining
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section III-A, Table I: The data sources used in this study are shown in Table I with their properties.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Builds a unified index for large-scale heterogeneous spatiotemporal data by dividing the map into spatial grids and organizing instances temporally in B+ trees.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section IV-A: At this stage, we build a unified index for large-scale heterogeneous spatiotemporal data (Fig. 2(a)) to enable faster data retrieval with different mining parameters specified and accelerate the subsequent mining stages.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Generates co-occurring instances with co-occurrence tables and pruning graphs by issuing range queries within spatial and temporal thresholds.
Inputs: Mining parameters (spatial distance, temporal window, co-occurrence coverage threshold)
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section IV-B: The proposed mining framework attempts to extract co-occurring instances with co-occurrence tables and pruning graphs (Fig. 3) from the spatiotemporal index built at the previous stage.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Finds significant combinations of co-occurring value ranges between properties by aggregating them into value matrices and applying a sweep-line algorithm.
Outputs: Low-level co-occurrence patterns (property pairs with co-occurring value ranges)
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section IV-C1: Low-level pattern mining aims to find significant combinations of the co-occurring value ranges between a property in the target data source and one in another data source by a) aggregating the co-occurring property value ranges... and b) performing a novel sweep-line based algorithm on the value matrices...

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Generates and validates high-level co-occurrence patterns by intersecting low-level patterns and validating them against co-occurrence coverage thresholds.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section IV-C2: High-level pattern candidates can be generated by intersecting low-level patterns. A pattern candidate is considered valid only if the number of the instance combinations it covers is larger than λe · |sτ |.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays the spatial distribution of pattern instances on a 2D map, with donut charts indicating the counts and ratios of selected pattern groups at each location.
Outputs: 2D map visualization with spatially aggregated donut charts
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-D: The top of the view shows the spatial distribution of the pattern instances on a map. In this study, we use air quality data as the target data source. Each air quality station is represented by a donut chart whose radius encodes the total number of pattern instances in this location.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Overlays the 2D map with donut charts to represent the ratios and counts of co-occurrence pattern instances at each spatial location.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-D: Each air quality station is represented by a donut chart whose radius encodes the total number of pattern instances in this location. The sectors in different colors indicate the ratios of the pattern instances of each group selected from CorView in each location.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays property combinations and their associated co-occurrence patterns using a matrix-based layout to provide a scalable overview and allow comparison.
Outputs: Matrix visualization of property combinations with co-occurrence summaries
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-B1: We adopt a scalable matrix-based approach (the volume challenge) to visualize the property combinations shared by massive co-occurrence patterns (R1) and provide an unified overview for the diverse data properties among the patterns (the diversity challenge).

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays co-occurrence patterns within a selected property combination using a similarity-based scatterplot to support grouping and anomaly detection.
Inputs: High-level co-occurrence patterns (filtered by property combination)
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-B2-a: A scatterplot is used to display the co-occurrence patterns, such that similar patterns are naturally grouped together. This scatterplot provides a concise overview of pattern relationships with less clutter than parallel coordinates.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays multidimensional co-occurrence patterns as parallel coordinates, with density maps encoding the distribution of value ranges for each property.
Inputs: High-level co-occurrence patterns (filtered by property combination)
Outputs: Parallel coordinates chart showing property co-occurrences
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-B2-b: Thus, parallel coordinates are used as a uniform view to display the multidimensional co-occurrence patterns. Each axis represents a property. The medians of the ranges are used as the end points of the line segments to connect the value ranges in various property axes.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Provides a compact visualization of grouped patterns, where the value ranges for each property are stacked to form a distribution map.
Outputs: Stacked line chart visualizing grouped pattern distributions
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-B2-c: In the chart, the value range for each property is represented by a fine line segment. The segments are stacked to compose a distribution map.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Visualizes the temporal distribution of pattern instances in STView, enabling selection of temporal windows for further filtering.
Outputs: Temporal histogram or line chart of instance distributions
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-D: The bottom of the view shows a histogram to visualize the temporal distributions of pattern instances with multiple scales.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays the statistical distributions of property value ranges in a line chart (upper part) and presents a range distribution in a stacked rectangle chart (lower part).
Outputs: Statistical distribution charts for value ranges of properties
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-C: StatView is used to display the pattern distribution of each property (Fig. 4) (R2). This pattern distribution comprises small multiples that display the distributions of the value ranges for the properties.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Provides a tabular display of pattern details, including property combinations, co-occurrence patterns, and their instance counts.
Outputs: Tabular display of detailed co-occurrence pattern data
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-E: PatTable is a table-like component that allows users to inspect raw patterns directly on demand.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Enables users to group patterns and highlight anomalies by brushing on scatterplots, allowing for comparison and focused exploration.
Outputs: Grouped patterns for comparison in visualizations
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-F: Users are allowed to group patterns or spot anomalies by brushing the patterns with colors in a scatterplot in CorView.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Enables filtering of pattern instances by spatial area on the map and temporal window on the timeline to refine analysis.
Outputs: Filtered patterns and pattern instances across views
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-F: Users can filter by spatial area, time range, and property value range in STView and StatView.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Allows users to change mining parameters such as spatial distance, temporal window, and co-occurrence coverage to adjust pattern extraction.
Outputs: New co-occurrence patterns based on user-specified parameters
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-F: Users can change the parameters including the spatiotemporal threshold and minimum co-occurrence coverage (Fig. 10(a)) and see new results (R5).
